page.lettertext:
fol.41r
May it please yo
r
good L. So long absence
of
e Deputies of
Guelderland
and
Overyssel
is greatly wondred at heere: and till all the
Deputies be mette, they can take no resolution
upon my Proposition. It is feared very muche
that some alteration of thinges at home, hath
staied their comming, or at
e lest their present
passadge: by reason of
e great inundations, in
sundrie places of these Provinces: as
e lyke was
never seene, of
e rivers and land waters, in
e
[.]
waters
memorie of any. For all
e Bettue, and Bommels
wert are overflowen, and a great part of
e c
o
trey
round about
Utrecht
and
Amersfort:
in so muche
as
e very gates of
e towne of Amersfort, the sub-
urbes of
Vianen,
and many dorpes and villages
are caried cleane away: and multitudes of people
to
e nomber, it is thought, of 3000 soules, are
drowned. And
e like is reported of
e land
about
Collen,
where
e waters are risen higher
by six foote, then hath bin hitherto knowen by any
recorde. Whiche is supposed to proceede of
e
great abundance of raine and snowe, that hath fallen
in these, and in
e upper contreis: and of
e long
continuance of this boistrous winde at west, whiche
hath forced the rivers to swelle out of measure.
I finde by conferring w
t
some of
e Scottishe
nation, that they are informed out of
Scotland,
that
Coronel Stuart
is enjoined by some secret
Instruction, to solicit
e states for a 1000 foote, and
500 horse, for 6 monethes, or rather for
e loane of
fol.41v
of so muche mony, as may serve for
e Lev
[ie of so]
many men, requesting 3 monethes pay to
[be deli-]
vered out of hand. W
ch
is imparted unt
[o me by]
suche persons of credit, as I in my conceat h
[ave rea-]
son to beleeve it. Nevertheles
e Coronel hi
[mself]
will not notifie so muche, not onely not to m
[e, but as]
farre as I perceave to none of
e states: pr
[oposing]
all as yet in general termes, and referring
[to them]
selves, to yelde what succo
r
they thinke bes
[t, which is]
thought to be done upon a hope that he hath,
[that they]
of themselves will offer more, then he hath [in charge]]
to presse them unto. For mine owne par
[t, the more]
that I consider of his imploim
t
hither, an
[d of the]
q
a
litie of his message,
e more me thinkes it
[doth tend]
to some designe to be disliked. For
[in proceeding]
wt these Provinces, the king hath gone by su
[ch degrees]
to winne upon their amitie, as I feare som
[ewhat else]
then this purpose pretended, of joining
[in alliance]
and of craving their assistance. If y
[our L call]
to minde, in Fe
b
last was two yeres,
[the States were]
moved by Stuart, being sent by the King
[to inter-]
taine from time to time a reciprocal
[intelligence]
in all affaires
at should concerne
[e religion and]
weale, of his and their contreis: w
ch
was
[presently obtai-]
ned. They were after sought unto,
[to renue the]
ancient league,
at had bin in former times
[between]
Scotland and them: whereunto they yelded, by th
[eir]
Deputies, at
e time of
e baptesme of
e yonge Princ
[e.]
Nowe thirdly they are intreated to assist him w
t
men or mony, wherof
e summe is so smalle, not amou
[n-]
ting to 8000
li
sterling for 3 monethes, as he might
fol.42r
very well presume, that they would not refuse him.
And when this shall be accorded, whether it be not
to be thought, that he hath yet an intention to gette
some further footing in their love and affection, and
to serve some other turnes w
t
their aide and support,
as his occasions shall require, and as it will be very
easie, when
e people of these contreis are once engaged
in his actions, I leave it as
a
motion to yo
r
L. wisedome.
The Coronel pretendeth that
e state of
e King
must be p
nt
ly relieved: and if it should be neglected
by his frindes and allies, it would engender, er be
long, some irreparable inconvenient, both to him and
to them. And this he doth inculcat in every c
o
panie
where he cometh, w
t
a fearefull declaration of
e w
a
tes
of
e King, and of
e strength of his ennemies: in so
muche as
e states, by that w
ch
I can gather, would
willingly doe for him, if my answear unto them, wherof
yo
r
L. had notice, in one from me of
e 22 of
e last,
doe not stoppe their proceeding. For so
e Coronel
hath told me, that he thought
e states resolution
would depend very muche up
o
her
Hig
es
allowance,
or onely up
o
me, that if I would but signifie, that
her Hig
es
would be pleased w
t
their aiding of the
King, there would be no stoppe: and he sawe not
just cause, for me to be scrupulous, sith every man
might see
e extremitie of
e King, and
at part of
the benefit would redound unto her Ma
tie
and all
the burden of
e aide up
o
e people of these Provinces.
I will not trouble yo
r
L. w
t
long rehersall of
my answears, and other speeches between us: but in
effect they were to pray him, to pardon my refusall
fol.42v
unles my warrant were better. For said
[I, to speak]
of maters roundly and familiarly between
[us, I may]
very well presume upon
e reasons yo
w
a
[lledge, that]
her Ma
tie
would be willing to advance
e
[K desire]
but yet it may be perhaps, that she will s
[oe much]
mislike of his forme of proceeding, as she wo
[uld have]
the states made acquainted w
t
her manifo
[ld endevors]
to free
e K. of his troubles. Lette it be, as
[yow]
give out,
at his state is reduced to pointes
[of extre-]
mitie, wherof I knowe very litle ether one w
[ay or]
other (though there be
at will avouche,
at
both his.]
perill is not suche, and
at it might have b
[in less, if]
he himself had listed) howe can yo
w
rep
[ort it here]
but they will p
nt
ly aske
e qestion, Why,
e
[
King
ha-]
ving tasted so long, and so largely of
[her Majesties]
bountie, and
e danger being neerer to
E[[ngland
]
then to them, he should not rather in this
[case, have]
recourse unto her Hig
es
or at
e lest ma
[ke her pri-]
vy, and request her advise, before he se
[nt to move]
the states? In yo
r
answear heerun
[to I know]
not howe yow will acquite yo
r
self: but
[you must]
w
t
out offense give me leave to suspect t
[hat yow]
will speake very litle in her Ma
ties
beha
[lf, but rather]
ther secretly complaine, in
e maneging of
[your busines]
that she hath not, or will not, doe
e part
[of a neighbor]
w
ch
may be so amplified in places where yo
w
[come]
as I doubt it may also tend, to worke some aliena[tion]
in
e hartes of this people, from their devotion to
her Hig
es
. And these are suche suspitions, or causes
of suspitions, as they force me to forbeare, and not
to meddle of or on, unles I had commission.
fol.43r
And therfor onely as before, I wishe
e states in
these proposals, to holde a sounde correspondence by ad-
vising w
t
her Hig
es
. As a man touched
neere, and guiltie, as it seemed, of some sinister dealing
(wherof I heare but too muche) he made a frivolous re-
plie, full of speeches at randon: w
ch
not being worthy
of yo
r
L. reading I leave unrehersed, very humbly
beseeching, that if yo
w
thinke it expedient, I may knowe
by yor direction, w
at
course I must observe, when I
speake in these affaires, to give her Ma
tie
good content.
I finde by a l
re
written from
e Frenche King
to
Mons
r
Buzanval
,
at he hath sent her Ma
tie
certaine
l
re
s intercepted, w
ch
were written in cipher by
father
Gordon
, and an other Scotte, to their correspondents
in Spaine, w
ch
e K. had caused to be deciphred.
Gordone is one
at is often named in
Cryttons
Latin l
re
w
ch
I sent yo
r
L. last: and I should conjecture
at
the notice of suche mater, as he hath written into
Spaine,
may easely laide to decipher
e l
re
s of Crytton in
Latin: w
ch
if it be not done already, if yo
r
L. thinke
it fitte to send me
e copie of Gordons l
re
, and
e others,
I will doe my best endevo
r
to discover
at of Crytton:
w
ch
I doe very muche presume, upon certaine c
o
jectures,
containe important mater, as
e conferring of some
princely state, or dignitie, or contrey, up
o
some special
person, upon whome
e chief hope of those fugitives
dependeth: wherein it also seemeth
at certaine great
personages are nominated actors.
And thus I take
my humble leave. From
e Hage. Ma
r
14
1594.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
